Quiz 1: Practice Quiz C

You are not logged in.

If you are a current student, please Log In for full access to the web site.
Note that this link will take you to an external site (https://shimmer.mit.edu) to authenticate, and then you will be redirected back to this page.

Please download the .zip file below, which contains all the files, test cases, etc., you need to complete the practice quiz using your own machine. When unzipped it will create its own directory with the quiz's files. The instructions follow below. You'll be editing quiz.py to add the code requested by the instructions.

Download: q1_practice_c.zip

How to take this practice quiz

Set aside a continuous block of time to attempt these problems. This is a past quiz so it can give you a feeling of what an actual quiz is like. During this quiz's semester, though, the quiz was closed book and closed Internet. As such, for the best practice experience, you should attend the quiz under those conditions.

Just like the labs, first run the tests on your computer before submitting online. Good luck!

Submission

When you have tested your code sufficiently on your own machine, you can submit your modified quiz.py below by clicking on "Choose File", then clicking the Submit button to send the file to the 6.009 server. In the real quiz, the server will queue your code and run the tests to score your quiz.

 No file selected

Instructions

This quiz assumes you have Python 3.6 (or a later version) installed on your machine.

This quiz is closed-book and closed-Internet -- you are only allowed to access the quiz page on the 6.009 website and the material provided in the .zip file. You are not allowed to access other information on your laptop or on the web. You may not discuss the quiz with other students, even after completion of the quiz, until regrades have been completed and final quiz grades assigned (at the end of next week), because many students will still be working on regrades or conflict offerings of the quiz. In the case of this practice quiz, however, you may discuss with other students as part of your preparation for the actual quiz.

In addition to the quiz.py and test.py files, you may also access the library.pdf file, which includes the chapters 1-4 of the Python Library Reference -- they cover the built-in functions (Chap. 2) and built-in data types (Chap. 4). Note that Python's built-in help function will provide a concise summary of built-in operations on data types (e.g., help(set)) or information about the arguments for the built-in functions (e.g., help(sorted)).

As in the labs, test.py can be used to test your code in quiz.py. Each of the problems has a suite of associated tests. You can run tests for a specific problem like so

python3 test.py problem1

or

pytest test.py -k problem1

This quiz is worth 20 points. Your quiz score will be based primarily on performance of your last code submitted during the quiz, tested against 20 test cases. However, points will also be lost in other circumstances:

  • You must not import any Python modules to use as part of your solutions -- quizzes with import statements (or their equivalent!) will be given grades of 0.

  • Having your code check for a specific input (called "hard coding") and then return a specific result is okay only for the base cases in iteration or recursion. Problem solutions that look for specific test case arguments other than base cases are disallowed and will receive no credit.

  • You do not have to include doctests or detailed comments in your code: we will not deduct any points for lack of comments, but encourage those as general good practice.

Aside from these special point deductions above, your quiz score will be based on the number of unittest tests your last submitted code passes. If you pass all of the tests, you'll receive full base credit. If you pass 15 of the 20 tests, you'll receive 75% of the base credit for the quiz (i.e., 15 points). Note also that to pass some of the tests in the time allotted, your solution may have to be reasonably efficient.

Problem 1. Batching Items Together: batch(inp, size) (5 points)

Write a function batch that conforms to the following specification:

def batch(inp, size):
    """
    Inputs:
      inp is a tuple of non-negative integers.
      size is a non-negative integer.

    Outputs:

    Return a list of batches, where each batch is a list of elements
    (in order from the beginning) from "inp", until the batch is
    populated with just enough elements to fill the batch. A batch
    is filled when the sum of the values of the elements in the
    batch is equal to or greater than "size", or if there are no more
    elements from "inp".

    >>> batch((13, 2, 3, 4, 3, 1, 1, 1, 4, 2, 3), 5)
    [[13], [2, 3], [4, 3], [1, 1, 1, 4], [2, 3]]

    >>> batch((6, 7, 6, 8, 6), 7)
    [[6, 7], [6, 8], [6]]

    """
    pass # Your code here

Problem 2. String Quasi-order: order(inp) (5 points)

Given a list of strings in inp, the function order should return a new list containing those strings but ordered in a special way: all strings that have the same first letter of the first string in the input should appear in the output first; next, all strings that share the starting letter of the first remaining string from the input (that has not already appeared in the ouput) should appear in the output; and so on. For those strings that share the same first letter, they should appear in the output in the same order that they appeared in the input. The examples below should clarify and explain the desired behavior. The input list should not be changed or mutated.

Example 1:

Input: ['hi', 'yes', 'hello', 'yay']
Output: ['hi', 'hello', 'yes', 'yay']
Since 'hi' came first in the input, we need all strings starting with letter 'h' to be grouped together in the output, in the order of their appearing in the input. The next (different) first letter that appears in the input is 'y' in 'yes', so all strings starting with 'y' come next in the output, again in their order of appearance in the input (thus 'yes' precedes 'yay').

Example 2:

Input: ['yes', 'hi', 'yay', 'hello']
Output: ['yes', 'yay', 'hi', 'hello']
This time, the 'y' strings come first, followed by the 'h' strings.

Example 3:

Input: ['b', 'ab', 'doh', 'aa', 'c', 'aa']
Output: ['b', 'ab', 'aa', 'aa', 'doh', 'c']
Note here that duplicated strings in the input appear an equal number of duplicated times in the output list.

Problem 3. The Good Life: path_to_happiness(field) (10 points)

Out walking one day, you encounter a field of smiles:

field = {"nrows": 2,
         "ncols": 3,
         "smiles": ((100, 3, 5), (2, 4, 6))}

The field has a given number of rows nrows and columns ncols, and a two-dimensional array smiles (as a tuple with nrows rows, each row being a tuple with ncols in it) giving the number of smiles at the respective row and column. Your goal is to find a path from left to right (from column 0 to column ncols-1) through the field, accumulating smiles as you go, that maximizes happiness, where happiness is defined as the sum of smiles along the path. All rows (r, 0) (for r values of 0 to nrows-1) are valid starting positions. Each subsequent step of the way, you must proceed to the next column by moving up one row, or staying in the same row, or moving down one row (of course, always staying on the field) until you come out the right side. Your task is to implement the function path_to_happiness(field) that takes a field as an input, and returns a maximum happiness path as a list of the row indices through the field that maximizes happiness.

To illustrate the specification, field = {"nrows": 2, "ncols": 3, "smiles": ((100, 3, 5), (2, 4, 6))} can be visualized as

100 3 5
2 4 6

For this example, path_to_happiness(field) should return path [0, 1, 1] that has happiness 110, corresponding to the red italicized path below:

100 3 5
2 4 6

As another example, for field2 below:

field2 = {"nrows": 3, "ncols": 2, "smiles": ((6, 25), (5, 2), (4, 35))}
6 25
5 2
4 35

path_to_happiness(field2) will produce the list [1, 2] with happiness 40, corresponding to the red italicized path below:

6 25
5 2
4 35

If there is more than one path with the same maximum happiness, your path_to_happiness can return any of them -- as in the field3 example below

field3 = {"nrows": 3, "ncols": 2, "smiles": ((5, 18), (6, 0), (4, 18))}
5 18
6 0
4 18

where path_to_happiness(field3) should produce either the list [1,0] with happiness 24, or the list [1,2] with happiness 24.

Hint: in general, if you know the maximum possible happiness value for the best paths up through each and every row in column c, it is possible to efficiently determine the optimal or maximum possible happiness values/paths up through each and every row in column c+1.

You can assume that all smile values in the field will be non-negative (no negative smiles, i.e., frowns, allowed!).

Note that in order to pass some of the test cases, your code will need to be efficient enough to run to completion within the specified timeout.

Each test case (not each Problem) must run in 1 second to receive credit. Exceptions: 'TestProblem1.test_batch_4' and TestProblem1.test_batch_5 must each run in 2 seconds. TestProblem3.test_path_to_happiness_10 must run in 10 seconds.
